description:
Zygotorulaspora mrakii is a species of yeast that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a member of the order Saccharomycetales and the family Saccharomycetaceae.

Zygotorulaspora mrakii is a haploid, unicellular organism that reproduces asexually through budding. The cells are typically round to oval in shape and range in size from approximately 3-8 micrometers in diameter.

This yeast species is commonly found in soil, plant material, and other natural environments. It is known to be involved in the fermentation of various food and beverage products, such as wine and kefir.

Zygotorulaspora mrakii is characterized by its ability to ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose. It is also capable of producing various metabolites, such as ethanol and carbon dioxide, as byproducts of its metabolic activities.

The species was first isolated and described by the mycologist Imre Márkus in 1964, and it was named in honor of the Hungarian microbiologist, Károly Mrak.
